guide.conclusion: The list seems long, but it's not really to difficult to put together. I pulled all the parts together one weekend, and then the following weekend, I put it up.

flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: This will give you all the information needed to plan, purchase and build a backyard zipline (and launch pad) without any specialized parts. I purchased everything at the local hardware stores. I did it 100% all by myself, and so can you.
guide.introduction_rendered:
This will give you all the information needed to plan, purchase and build a backyard zipline (and launch pad) without any specialized parts. I purchased everything at the local hardware stores. I did it 100% all by myself, and so can you.

Relevant parts
  • Wire Rope 1/4in
  • Wire Rope clip 1/4in
  • D Ring
  • Wire Rope Thimble
  • Turnbuckle 5/8 X9 or 5/8 X 12
  • Eye hook large
  • bungie rope
  • scrap 2x4
  • bolts/washers/locknuts for brake block
  • T strap
  • Pulley
Tools
  • 4000 Lb. Capacity Cable Winch Puller
  • Adjustable wrench
  • Hammer
  • cable/bolt cutter
  • hand-held electric drill

parts.notes: Length based on run length.  I recommend getting at least 10 feet more than the length of the run.  This allows from wrapping the tree, and aids in tensioning the cable
used at both ends of the cable and also on the trolley
length based on distance from brake tree or pole.
this is for the brake block, should be about 8 inches long. It's a doubled up and has a notch cut in it.
these 4 bolts will hold your brake block locked onto the wire rope, and hold the bungie line to the brake tree

This is used to form the frame of the trolley.
Use 6 sandwiched together to form the two sides of the trolley. This holds both the pulleys and also the D ring from which the rope hangs.   Generally this is found in the framing section of the big box stores
This is acctually one of the harder items to find. I started off with 2 550lbs units from a big box store. Ideally a 2" or 3" unit with bearings.

lines.text: Pick out the trees you are going to use.  I had a 100ft span to work with. I think for the effort that goes into this, it's probably the minimum length.
lines.text_raw: Pick out the trees you are going to use.  I had a 100ft span to work with. I think for the effort that goes into this, it's probably the minimum length.

lines.text: Purchase your parts, and then dry fit everything.
lines.text_raw: Purchase your parts, and then dry fit everything.

lines.text: decide how high you want to land at the end of the run
lines.text_raw: decide how high you want to land at the end of the run

lines.text: decide how long you want the rope which will hand down from the trolley
lines.text_raw: decide how long you want the rope which will hand down from the trolley

lines.text: Now that you have everything measured, lets start building!
lines.text_raw: Now that you have everything measured, lets start building!

lines.text: Starting with the tree on the high side, loop the cable around the tree and tighten the three cable ties. You place the first one as tight as you can, then the rest are placed closer to the tree, this will tighten the loop a little more each time.
lines.text_raw: Starting with the tree on the high side, loop the cable around the tree and tighten the three cable ties. You place the first one as tight as you can, then the rest are placed closer to the tree, this will tighten the loop a little more each time.

lines.text: You can place a garden hose around the tree, or place some blocks to lessen the strain on the tree if you wish.
lines.text_raw: You can place a garden hose around the tree, or place some blocks to lessen the strain on the tree if you wish.

lines.text: TIP: if you tap a couple of nails in the tree it will hold the cable in the right place until there is tension to hold it in place.
lines.text_raw: TIP: if you tap a couple of nails in the tree it will hold the cable in the right place until there is tension to hold it in place.

lines.text: Success! You have one end of the zip line complete.
lines.text_raw: Success! You have one end of the zip line complete.

lines.text: On the low end of the line, tap a couple of nails into the tree to hold the chain at the right height.
lines.text_raw: On the low end of the line, tap a couple of nails into the tree to hold the chain at the right height.

lines.text: Wrap the chain around the tree and connect the ends together with a strong D ring.
lines.text_raw: Wrap the chain around the tree and connect the ends together with a strong D ring.

lines.text: Open the turnbuckle as far as it can be. Then attach one end to the D ring connected to the chain.
lines.text_raw: Open the turnbuckle as far as it can be. Then attach one end to the D ring connected to the chain.

lines.text: At this step, I placed another D ring to the other end of the turnbuckle. You can leave it out if you want.
lines.text_raw: At this step, I placed another D ring to the other end of the turnbuckle. You can leave it out if you want.

lines.text: It's important that before you begin the next step, that you have a few things in place and ready.  make sure you have your come-along ready and that you understand how it works.
lines.text_raw: It's important that before you begin the next step, that you have a few things in place and ready.  make sure you have your come-along ready and that you understand how it works.

lines.text: Extend the cable in the come-along almost as far as it will go, and find a tree to connect it to. Ideally it will cross across the path of the zip line.
lines.text_raw: Extend the cable in the come-along almost as far as it will go, and find a tree to connect it to. Ideally it will cross across the path of the zip line.

lines.text: I used a tree strap and a large shackle to connect it to the come along
lines.text_raw: I used a tree strap and a large shackle to connect it to the come along

lines.text: Now that your come along is ready, place a thimble on the D ring connected to the turnbuckle and then thread the cable through it
lines.text_raw: Now that your come along is ready, place a thimble on the D ring connected to the turnbuckle and then thread the cable through it

lines.text: Now that you have the cable threaded through the D ring and on the thimble, bring it back to ground level and figure out how much cable you have available and then put a thimble and cable ties at the point where you can hook up the come along.
lines.text_raw: Now that you have the cable threaded through the D ring and on the thimble, bring it back to ground level and figure out how much cable you have available and then put a thimble and cable ties at the point where you can hook up the come along.

lines.text: This step is difficult to explain. Ideally you will only make this long enough to start adding tension to the line.
lines.text_raw: This step is difficult to explain. Ideally you will only make this long enough to start adding tension to the line.

lines.text: Tighten the cable with the come-along
lines.text_raw: Tighten the cable with the come-along

lines.text: Add the cable ties to the cable and tighten.
lines.text_raw: Add the cable ties to the cable and tighten.

lines.text: Once the cable ties are tight, you can remove tension from the come-along.
lines.text_raw: Once the cable ties are tight, you can remove tension from the come-along.

lines.text: Now you can start to tighten the turnbuckle.
lines.text_raw: Now you can start to tighten the turnbuckle.

lines.text: Please exercise caution whenever you are tightening the cable.
lines.text_raw: Please exercise caution whenever you are tightening the cable.

lines.text: Don't try and tighten the turnbuckle all the way at this time. you will come back and re-tighten everything at a later step.
lines.text_raw: Don't try and tighten the turnbuckle all the way at this time. you will come back and re-tighten everything at a later step.

lines.text: Assemble the trolley:
lines.text_raw: Assemble the trolley:

lines.text: Using Grade 8 bolts! don't use cheap bolts, remember, your kids are going to be riding on this.
lines.text_raw: Using Grade 8 bolts! don't use cheap bolts, remember, your kids are going to be riding on this.

lines.text: Take the T braces and connect them to the pulleys and the spacer. Place the D ring on the spacer.
lines.text_raw: Take the T braces and connect them to the pulleys and the spacer. Place the D ring on the spacer.

lines.text: I placed the bracket stack in a large vise to form a nice bend around the pulley and spacer, but this is optional.
lines.text_raw: I placed the bracket stack in a large vise to form a nice bend around the pulley and spacer, but this is optional.

lines.text: Tie an anchor knot to the D ring using the rope that will be suspended from the trolley
lines.text_raw: Tie an anchor knot to the D ring using the rope that will be suspended from the trolley

lines.text: Assemble the brake block
lines.text_raw: Assemble the brake block

lines.text: cut two 2x4's to approximately 8 inches in length each.
lines.text_raw: cut two 2x4's to approximately 8 inches in length each.

lines.text: Use a table saw to cut a notch lengthwise in the block.
lines.text_raw: Use a table saw to cut a notch lengthwise in the block.

lines.text: drill 5 holes for the bolts and the eye-hook.
lines.text_raw: drill 5 holes for the bolts and the eye-hook.

lines.text: cut the wire support from the bicycle tire
lines.text_raw: cut the wire support from the bicycle tire

lines.text: dry fit the brake block together. Make sure that it's easy to assembly because you will be putting it together at the top of a ladder
lines.text_raw: dry fit the brake block together. Make sure that it's easy to assembly because you will be putting it together at the top of a ladder

lines.text: Tie your chain around the brake tree. Attach it together with a D ring
lines.text_raw: Tie your chain around the brake tree. Attach it together with a D ring

guide.summary: Want to create a backyard zipline, don't know where to start? I was in the same situation recently and figured out how to do it with just a little bit of research. This project can be accomplished in just one weekend.
guide.title: Backyard Zipline

tools.notes: essentially you need something capable of cutting your wire rope. It could be a bolt cutter, a cable cutter, a dremel with a cutoff bit, a hack saw, just depends on what you have available. I used a large bolt cutter and the process to about 2 seconds...
